instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
Hi

Got a no back-light unit

Backlight circuit looks good

R5117 completely burned out thou, cant attach it back as both points are also burned out.
Any tips how to attach the replacement?

Closer inspection revealed that the Q5158 also has damage on the CPU_THRMTRIP_3V3 line

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message: Those have nothing to do with backlight...what voltage do you get on BKLT output? There is a great guide on the pinned posts from Louis btw

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
Lot of information on the forum.
Especially 3437 and 00165 Air boards; just use search function.

Rebuild CPU_THRMTRIP_3V3 trace from Q5158 to SMC area.
Then solder R5117 to that line and wire its other pad to nearest 3V42 point...

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
Thanks.
Ok, I will dig deeper with the backlight issue

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
ok

continuity between D7701 and A5 ball of U7701 

(all voltages taken with screen connected, psu connected, no battery)

D7701 8.51V

Q7706 voltages 
1 - 0.02v
2 - 0.02v
3 - 2.8v

4 - 8.5v
5 - 8.5v
6 - 8.5v


F7700 was ok but I shorted it while measuring voltage ( touched both the shield and the fuse - probe slipped :/ )
It had continuity before thou and no backlight so I am guessing that this wasnt the issue

Also I am getting a short to ground on PPBUS_G3H, when I hold the multimeter for a few seconds it kinda drains and short goes but when checked later - it does the same (is that relevant at all?)

Still have to work on that CPU_THRMTRIP_3V3

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message: Are you measuring resistance with power applied??? I hope not as that's a good way to mess up your multimeter...if you have 8.6 you don't have any kind of short on PPBUS. Sounds like bad LED Driver to me. BKLT_EN resistors ok?

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
That was the case. I have learned something today :)
No short now
R7788 - 300koms
R7789 - 146 kOms
Looking fine

Will replace f7700 and investigate further

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message: F7700 is fine if you have 8 volts..replace the LED Driver and see what happens.

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
"D7701 8.51V"
Which pin?
Backlight output is on K pin...

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
[B][URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/member/1153-johnb8812"]JohnB8812[/URL] [/B]F7700 was fine but I accidentally killed it after taking the measurement
[B][URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/member/682-2informaticos"]2informaticos[/URL] [/B]PIN 2 according to the schematics, the other pin was 0v

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
"PIN 2 according to the schematics, the other pin was 0v"
According to schematic, D7701 has two pins, A and K.
And is impossible to have 0V at same time with a voltage on these pins; unless diode is burnt!

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message: Replace F7700 again then and remeasure. If 8 volts, then replace LED Driver.

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
[B][URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/member/682-2informaticos"]2informaticos[/URL][/B] my bad, I was thinking about the boardview

new f7700 in place

D7701 8.5v on both sides

Is that the led driver then?

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
Post diode mode readings on all conections of U7701; red probe to ground.
Also post BKL_PWM/EN voltages; LCD connected, of course...

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
ok

U7701

Pins

1 0.002
2 0.002
3 0.564
4 0.0
5 started burning - most likely I put the wrong probe on but cant say as I dropped it 
disconnected from power and rechecked the f7700, will have to replace it again
Pin 4 is now in -1.8
Just thinking - was my mistake measuring it while powered on?

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message: Do NOT measure diode mode with power applied! Replace F7700 and just replace the driver. Wasting time measuring when you?ll know right away if it?s the chip or not replacing it...

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message: Cheers. I am such a dummy. I dont do it often enough to remember :/

threads.message:

Post some voltages for U7701; 3, 4, 11, 14.

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message:
U7701 has needed signals and power to work.

"15 - 0"
Short to ground???
Should have similar value like other BKL_ISENx lines...

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message: 15 - 0v but no short to ground - I measure this on R7719

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
threads.message: So there is your problem...

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 820-00165A
